instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>         <SIGNAL>PP5V_MAIN_ALSCAM_F</SIGNAL> short "burnt coil" (using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board view)
threads.message:
I have seen this a few times but never really fixed it.
The <SIGNAL>PP5V_MAIN_ALSCAM_F</SIGNAL> fail was dead at J8550.   A burnt inductor was obvious on the LB.

Repaired the damaged traces and was able to return power to <SIGNAL>PP5V_MAIN_ALSCAM_F</SIGNAL> at J8550 but still no display.

These machines come in for damaged displays and when they replace the screens and they still don't work I end up with them.  I was  wondering if anyone has figured out what else gets damaged when this goes.   There is a similar fault on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and my repairs have met a similar fate.   All the rails on J8550 are present and the machine does boot just no image.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>         <SIGNAL>PP5V_MAIN_ALSCAM_F</SIGNAL> short "burnt coil" (using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board view)
threads.message:
Do you mean J8500?

L8570 usually fails because of short in the video flex, inside LCD panel.
Liquid spill inside of video connectors can also generate such issue.
The big problem is that some camera data lines go to T2, there is not a separate camera chip (like in previous models).
<CHIP>U8595</CHIP> doesn't completely separate camera and T2.

I think T2 maintains a relation between camera, LCD connector and eDP output.
Check diode mode to ground on data lines of camera and eDP.
Also try changing <CHIP>U8595</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>         <SIGNAL>PP5V_MAIN_ALSCAM_F</SIGNAL> short "burnt coil" (using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board view)
threads.message: so <CHIP>U8570</CHIP> can cause no image on the screen?  or just problems with the camera?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>         <SIGNAL>PP5V_MAIN_ALSCAM_F</SIGNAL> short "burnt coil" (using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board view)

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>         <SIGNAL>PP5V_MAIN_ALSCAM_F</SIGNAL> short "burnt coil" (using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board view)
threads.message:
sorry <CHIP>U8595</CHIP>
The one you were talking about.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>         <SIGNAL>PP5V_MAIN_ALSCAM_F</SIGNAL> short "burnt coil" (using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board view)
threads.message:
If you are sure the short inside display assembly didn't affect video lines, try changing <CHIP>U8595</CHIP>.

Do you get external video?
